awd_titl_txt: Clusters, Heritage and the Microfoundations of Spillovers - Lessons from Semi-Conductors
awd_abstract_narration:
Knowledge industries tend to cluster geographically, which has long been thought to promote spillovers of knowledge through local employees of competing firms exchanging know-how and changing employers.  Employees of incumbent firms also sometimes found their own spinoff firms, which can be a source of knowledge spillovers. 

Intellectual Merit: The main purpose of the proposed work is to assess the strength of these alternative spillover mechanisms and their effect on firm performance in the context of the semiconductor industry, which famously clustered in Silicon Valley and secondarily in Boston, New York, and Los Angeles.  Sorting out the importance of these alternative mechanisms is critical; if clusters promote knowledge exchange and employee mobility then clustering is socially beneficial whereas if spinoffs are the primary conduit for clustering then the benefits of clusters do not extend beyond spinoffs and their 'parents'.  Using an annual buyers' guide, data are collected on the location and products of all semiconductor producers from the inception of the industry through 1987.  Firm sales data are collected to identify the market leaders.  The pre-entry experience of each producer is traced using the annual buyers' guides to identify prior producers of other electronics producers and trade journals and web sources are used to identify spinoffs and their parents. The patents assigned to each semiconductor producer and the inventors of the patents are collected to trace the mobility of the inventors over time. An analysis is conducted of the influence of location and other factors on whether semiconductor producers entered producing semiconductor products at the technological frontier, and if not whether they later shifted to produce frontier products. The determinants of the mobility of inventors are analyzed, including whether mobility was greater for inventors in clusters. Various new semiconductor products were developed in the sample period, and analyses are conducted of the factors influencing whether firms adopted new products, including the role of location.  All of these decisions are in turn related to the performance of firms, as reflected in their sales and longevity.

Broader Impact: Understanding whether clusters improve firm performance and the main mechanisms behind regional knowledge diffusion can yield important broader impacts for both strategy and policy. If direct knowledge sharing and inter-firm employee mobility are promoted by clustering and in turn contribute to clustering, then clustering has clear welfare benefits and would also benefit firms located in clusters. Alternatively, if spinoffs are the primary conduit for clustering, then external economies do not go beyond spinoffs and their 'parents' and clustering provides no social benefits per se nor any private benefits to firms located in clusters.

Firms located in clusters are believed to benefit from knowledge spillovers from neighboring firms, creating self-reinforcing “agglomeration economies” that benefit all located in the cluster.  However, Carnegie Mellon researchers studying the evolution of the semiconductor industry in Silicon Valley and throughout the country show that spillovers appear to have been mainly confined to spinoffs and their parents, suggesting that clusters might not confer on their members as many benefits as believed. This is the core  intellectual contribution of the project.

Silicon Valley is famous for job-hopping, with employees frequently changing employers within the region.  High mobility in this region has long been thought to be driven by the proximity of producers, and to benefit all firms in the cluster through the diffusion of knowledge brought about by the movement of labor. Judging from the flows of semiconductor inventors analyzed in the project, mobility was indeed markedly higher in Silicon Valley, with patenters in this region changing employers much more frequently than patenters elsewhere. Yet, the analysis shows that such high mobility is due primarily to firm entry, and spinoffs in particular, not the clustering of the industry in Silicon Valley. Inventor moves from parents to spinoffs, and to other recent entrants, accounted for most of the greater mobility of inventors in Silicon Valley. After excluding these movements in calculating the regions’ inventor mobility rates, the remaining inventor mobility was similar across time periods and across regions (see table 1). This suggests that the higher rate of inventor mobility in Silicon Valley was not due to the clustering of the industry there, which increased over time. This finding questions the importance of what is considered a critical spillover conduit in a cluster.

While mobility is seen as an important conduit for knowledge transfer and thus a cornerstone for the relevance of a cluster, the ultimate measurement of cluster effectiveness is firm performance. In the semiconductor industry, producing at the technological frontier, which became the monolithic integrated circuit (IC), was a necessary condition to achieve a leading market share (Table 2). Firms located in Silicon Valley were much more likely to produce monolithic ICs, which imparted them with an advantage that fueled the superior performance of the region. Having started from zero, Silicon Valley captured the leadership of the industry, reaching 50% of the industry sales by 1987.  But the project concludes that the technical preeminence of Silicon Valley firms was mainly inherited through a spinoff process whereby employees of existing firms left to found their own IC companies.

Firms in Silicon Valley were much more likely to enter at the technical frontier than firms located elsewhere, including those located in other IC clusters such as New York, Boston, and Los Angeles. Yet, this happened because nearly all the semiconductor entrants in Silicon Valley were descended either directly or indirectly from Fairchild Semiconductor, the leading producer of monolithic integrated circuits in the industry, not necessarily because of their Silicon Valley location. Moreover, while spillovers across co-located firms are thought to enable firms in industry clusters to be closer to the technological frontier and improve their performance, our findings show that being in a cluster did not help IC firms move to the frontier. In fact, if a firm did not produce monolithic ICs at entry, the likelihood that it ever came to produce monolithic ICs was small (less than 10 percent) and equivalent whether firm was in Silicon Valley or in any other region of the USA.
